subject: New York, New York
event:
I'm not one of those fair weather football fans.  I've always believed that your team is your team, and you root for them every week of every season, whether they are good, bad, or indifferent.  

That being sad, it was hard to be a Giants fan this past weekend.  Their play against the Saints was absolutely disgraceful.  This is an enormously talented team that seems to have no heart, no head, and no discipline.  Tom Coughlin needs to be fired.  For all the talk about what a hard-ass he is, he actually seems to be a candy-ass when it comes to disciplining his team.  Bob Whitfield helped blow a game a couple of weeks ago when he head-butted an opponent after a play was over, drawing a fifteen yard unsportsmanlike conduct penalty.  Pretty stupid for a fifteen-year veteran, but okay, everyone gets angry sometimes.  Then, against the Saints, Whitfield does EXACTLY THE SAME THING again, head-butting a Saint after the play and drawing another fifteen yarder.  At that point, Coughlin should have shown the idiot to the bench and sat him down for the rest of the game... but no, he keeps him in, and sure enough, a couple quarters later, Whitfield gets ANOTHER costly fifteen-yard penalty.  This is NOT discipline.  

And Eli... don't get me started.  If Coughlin had any guts, Eli would have been benched by now.  Parcells did not hesitate to bench Drew Bledsoe and insert Tony Romo at halftime in the first game between the Cowboys and the G-Men, and it turned the entire Cowboys season around.  Last night, Nick Saban pulled Joey Harrington and inserted Cleo Lemon for the Dolphins against the Jets, and the week before, in Minnesota, Brad Childress sat down Brad Johnson and put in Tavaris Jackson.  The Jets won both those games, true, but in both cases the new QB gave the team a much-needed spark.  I can't help but wonder if Jared Lorenzen might not provide the same sort of spark for the Giants.  The kid is huge and raw and has an absolute cannon for an arm, and he looked pretty good in pre-season, but it has become plain that Coughlin is never going to give him a chance, no matter how badly Eli Manning plays. 

Pfui.  I say, fire Coughlin, and play the Hefty Lefty.  

The weird thing is, the Giants still have a good chance to sneak into the playoffs.  If they do, they will be the worst playoff team of all time.  It's a disgrace, really.  Tiki deserved to go out on top, not like this.  

On the other hand, I have the Jets, who won another good one last night against the Dolphins.  That was a lovely Xmas present.  Nearly gave me a coronary, however.  I went out to Christmas dinner with some friends, so I did not watch the game live.  No problem, though, I had TIVO set up to record it for me, so after everyone went home I settled down in front of the television to watch.  The first three quarters were not the most exciting football I've ever seen, it must be said -- it was pouring in Miami, and in the steady rain neither offense could seem to get untracked.  There was some good hitting, though, and both teams hung in there.  The Jets had a 3-0 lead at the end of the third quarter, but then Nick Saban went to Cleo Lemon at QB and suddenly the Dolphins came alive.  They roared down the field for a TD, but the Jets came right back with a TD of their own on a great toss from Chad to Jericho, who stretched out like Plastic Man as he was falling to get the ball across the goal.  With time running out, the Jets D rose up and stopped the Dolphins three-and-out, and I thought the game might be safely in hand... until a lousy, short punt took a bad hop and hit one of the Jets in the back and the Dolphins recovered deep in Jets territory.  My heart lurched.  The Jets have a long history of having games and seasons destroyed by freak plays like this, strange moments that somehow turn everything around... and sure enough, the Dolphins took the ball and were advancing deep into Jets territory for a go-ahead TD or a tying field goal, and then... URK... my TIVO recording ended abruptly!!!  The game had run past its allotted slot.

So I never saw the end.  Fortunately for my sanity, the end was a good one.  The Dolphins did indeed tie it up, and the ensuing kickoff had the Jets back deep in their own territory, but then Little Leon the rookie broke a 64-yard run on a screen pass, and Mike Nugent kicked a game-winning field goal as time ran out.

What hey.  Maybe these aren't the Same Old Jets.  The Same Old Jets would certainly have fallen apart after the punt took that freak hop, but these Jets bore down and came back.  Leon was great... but I have to credit Chad and Eric Mangini as well.  

Of course, the acid test will come next weekend, when the Jets host the dismal Raiders.  Win, and they are in the playoffs.  The Raiders are 2-13.  Nonetheless, the Same Old Jets of years past would find a way to lose and snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.  Can Mangini prevent that?  We shall see.  A Jets fan never makes assumptions.

As for the Giants... I want Charlie Weis and Scott Pioli next season, thank you very much.  If Weis can't turn Eli around, no one can... but if that happens, I'd hope that at least Charlie would have the guts to try Lorenzen.  Let's see what the Pillsbury Throw Boy can do!

comments.article:
Duuhh ???
I am not an US citizen, I really don't care about US football.
So, I know it's your website, but tell us something about A song Of Ice and Fire instead.

I am sure I am not the only one to visit this site only to get some news about your book.
comments.subject: bah..us football is not that interesting

comments.article: hi my name is personal blog obviously we have not met

comments.article:
What the coach of the Giants did was wrong. Very wrong.
But then again - seen pessimistically, of course - he did what he did for a reason. Not good for the team, but maybe good for his wallet. *shrugs*
A gross thing, but it happens.
Hope you had a lovely X-mas despite of that!
Heh, don't get me started. No, wait, it's too late.
comments.subject: Those New York teams look pretty good from here

comments.article:
*sniffles*

Damnable Jets...
are you a Fish fan feeling the hurt?

I completely understand the "my team" concept. Growing up, mine was the Minnesota Vikings. I still have a soft spot in my heart for them, but I don't follow them religiously...

...because I have to root for Seattle. It's a city ordinance, you know; mandatory fan participation in the form of funding a stadium with massive government outlay despite huge public opposition (long story). In any event, rooting for the Seahawks is painful. Despite having some decent talent, they manage to lose games they should have won, and won games they shouldn't. They backed into the playoffs this year and shouldn't be there. I don't expect them to go far.

In the end, I'm a much bigger fan of college football, especially my beleaguered Washington Huskies.

Lol! I've lived here for going on 14 years, so I am a mandatory Seahawks fan too! I wish I had another team to root for some years!

And the Huskies? Lord don't even get me started on the Cougs... we could have had a bowl game *grumble grumble* It's also my senior year so I wanted to see us do well again at least once before graduation!

Yes, the Giants AND Coughlin might be better off if he has a change of scenery next fall. As for the Hefty Lefty: Romo has been fairly unique in his ability to spur a team off the bench. The history of the NFL is littered with the bodies of coaches who played the second guy because he wasn't on the field. The fans may want him, but it doesn't mean 1) that he would play any better than Eli, just different and 2) that is he came in and was trashed that it might not hurt his future. Bringing up baby QBs is all about timing.

J.....E.....T.....S! JETS! JETS! JETS!!!

Have to admire the way they've scrapped together a season and been motivated beyond their ability by that kid/coach just out of diapers. And, it gives me someone to root for instead of a team that employs Jeremy Shockey!!! :-)

This is NOT discipline.

Nope, it's roid rage.

I feel for you with your N.Y. teams...what you really should do is come to the dark side and just turn to my Pats. You know you would love for Pioli to leave us...but I hope he stays on. Mr. Kraft will hopefully make him an offer he can't refuse, and he'll stay on. That said, I think if the Jets make it in, I'd rather face the Broncos then the Jets. I think Mangini knows our personel far too well...and the Bronco's are really seeming to struggle lately.
comments.subject: Pioli and Charlie

comments.article:
Hehe. Only GRRM can write about a viewing of a TiVoed football game in such a way as to make it seem as interesting (to a Eurocommie) as a jousting match between Rhaegar Targaryen and Jaime Lannister on dragons. ;-)
For this, Mr Martin, you deserve a team that always wins.

Coughlin's gotta go, but do you really believe J. Lo would give us a better chance to win then Eli? There have certainly been games where Eli's play has helped us lose, but the kid's won too many in the final quarter to bench him for an inexperienced and unproven third year backup.
comments.subject: Coughlin yes, Eli... not yet...

comments.article:
I'm confused! Is this the american football thing, or the european one (soccer?). Never really understood the american football (rugby, or is that something else? AAARGH!)... I'm so confused. :)

Swedish football, go, go, go! :D
I have no clue what swedish football is. But this is American football, which is completely different from rugby and not even related to european football (soccer) except by name.

As another Seattlite (and football fan) I have to say I think the Seahawks may be the worst team with the most talent going into the playoffs this year. In any other division they wouldn't even be wild card material, but I guess we lucked out and everyone else in our division is even worse, or in worse shape. It is amazing to think that the Seahawks and the Steelers were both in the Super Bowl last year. You would never know it watching their seasons this year.
BTW, I love that you are a football fan, not what one would expect.

As bad as the Giants were this weekend, my Steelers may have been even worse. How does a team go from Superbowl champs to missing the playoffs so quickly? eeeeeeeeek. They are just ugly to watch.

I don't know if we are missing The Bus that much, or if Big Ben was bothered by his off-season foibles and injuries, or what..... Hopefully they'll get the ship righted next season, but right now they are just dreadful. And what's worse, it was BALTIMORE that humiliated them at home, and officially ended their slim post-season chances. Ugh.

I sorry you are feeling so glum about the Giants.. I can't complain though. I and all other Eagles fans got a great christmas present yesterday. After being left for dead 4 weeks ago they have risen from the ashes on the back of a backup QB. Yes I can see how the right backup, with the right attitude, can really fire up a team. It also helps that Jeff Garcia was a 3 time pro bowl QB and REALLY knows how to play the game. Although I really don't want to play the Giants again. Eli [the interception machine] can come up big on occasion and the rivalry is unpredictable.

Well, Have a Happy New Year and I look forward to you next installment, either in Not A Blog or book for.

BG905
comments.subject: Football

comments.article:
*said with a wink and a sly smile*

You should start watching hockey. You can slam into a man at over 120k per hour, you can whip a hard rubber disc at them even faster, and if all of that fails, you can fight. Hence, no petty head butts when revenge is a PART of the game.

Seriously. One game of playoff hockey IS the most exciting sporting event in the world, then you could stop worrying abou the Giants and jets. (Not crappin' on your teams, but you've got a bit to worry about there).

What was that?
Oh, yeah. Totally from Canada.

Keep up the gud wurk!!!!!!

*rolls eyes*
Canadians...
; )

Agreed on Coughlin... so glad he's no longer with my hometown team, Jacksonville. :)

--sam
Somehow, I don't think Charlie's going anywhere.

Hate to say it George, but next year looks pretty grim too...no Tiki. He's always been one of my favorite and, in my opinion, most underrated players in the NFL. They will sorely miss him and I think they will find themselves in a bind next year when they see how...limited...Brandon Jacobs is.

And to think that at the beginning of the season, people were slamming Chad Pennington before the season. Good for him, dude was a Rhodes scholar!

Amen to the Tiki comments, but.... Limited? Brandon Jacobs? Hrm. I see amazing footwork and startling speed for such a big guy, and obviously lots of power. He still doesn't get low enough and could make some better decisions when the hole isn't where it should be, but I'm confident he'll impress a lot of people next year.

I figure worst case we get Gary Brown from 1998-99 (not a bad thing), best case, Bettis-esque.

I'm not one of those fair weather football fans. I've always believed that your team is your team, and you root for them every week of every season, whether they are good, bad, or indifferent.

I feel the same way, though I suspect that I'm actually a masochist- I'm a Bills fan. ;)
Ouch.

comments.upictitle: Save the Cheerleader, Save the World: Brothels and Pirates
comments.article:
Oh George, I wish I could say I was sorry the Giants lost, but I can't! The Saints are finally winning and I'm excited!

Hope you had a Merry Christmas and have an awesome New Year!
It's my SOP to pad sports events I'm going to Tivo.  I usually make sure to have 30-60 minutes of extra time, so I don't miss the end of any game.
I agree that the Giants should put in Lorenzen. I can't wait for the first TV announcer that gets confused  and asks why the offensive lineman keeps taking snaps.
Go Panthers!
